item.title: From battleships to buildings: Trump's name is everywhere
item.description: As a New York businessman, President Donald Trump put his name on real estate, golf courses, vodka, steaks, bottled water and his own university. As president in his second term, he is merging his personal brand with national institutions and government programs, an unusual assertion of power by a

item.title: Rooted in Feni: The neem tree that bears Khaleda’s memory
item.description: At the gate of Majumdar Bari in Fulgazi, Feni, a neem tree planted decades ago by BNP Chairperson Khaleda Zia still stands, quietly preserving a living memory of her ties to the ancestral home. Back in 2008, during a visit to her ancestral house, Majumdar Bari at Shreepur village of Fulgazi Upazil

item.title: Myanmar junta says voter turnout at 52pc in first phase of election
item.description: Myanmar's junta said slightly more than half of eligible voters cast their ballot in the first phase of a three-stage national election at the weekend, a figure that was markedly lower than the previous two elections. The election is the first since a 2021 coup and is taking place during a civil w

item.title: Drugmakers raise US prices on 350 medicines despite pressure from Trump
item.description: Drugmakers plan to raise US prices on at least 350 branded medications including vaccines against COVID, RSV and shingles and blockbuster cancer treatment Ibrance, even as the Trump administration pressures them for cuts, according to data provided exclusively by healthcare research firm 3 Axis Adv

item.title: BNP vows to walk Khaleda’s path
item.description: Millions stood shoulder to shoulder beneath an open winter sky as Bangladesh bid farewell to Khaleda Zia—a leader whose political life was defined by defiance, endurance and unyielding belief in democracy. Moments before her funeral prayers, the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) pledged to

item.title: Adieu 2025, welcome 2026!
item.description: As the sun sinks into a red glow on the western horizon on the final day of 2025, a year that witnessed many upheavals, the people of Bangladesh step into another year of their short span of life, yet carrying hopes for something better in the New Year. The final days of 2025 felt a story imbued w

item.title: Four injured, including three children in Russian attack on Odesa, Ukraine says
item.description: Russia launched an overnight drone attack on Ukraine’s Odesa region, damaging residential buildings and infrastructure and injuring four people, including three children, regional authorities said on Wednesday. Odesa, a major Black Sea port, has been repeatedly targeted by Russian missiles a

item.title: Guinea junta chief wins presidential election by landslide
item.description: Guinea’s junta chief Gen Mamady Doumbouya has won the presidential election by a landslide, getting 86.7% of the vote, according to provisional results published by the election commission. The general is hoping to legitimise his rule after seizing power in a coup in 2021, reports BBC. A ci

item.title: Indian FM, Pakistani speaker meet in Dhaka
item.description: India’s External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar and Pakistan National Assembly Speaker Sardar Ayaz Sadiq exchanged greetings in Dhaka while visiting the capital to pay their final respects to Khaleda Zia. The exchange took place ahead of Khaleda’s Janaza, the Chief Advisor’s Offic

item.title: China imposes curbs on beef imports to protect domestic industry
item.description: China will impose an added 55% tariff on beef imports that exceed quota levels from key supplier countries including Brazil, Australia and the U.S. in a move to protect a domestic cattle industry slowly emerging from oversupply. China’s commerce ministry said on Wednesday the total import qu

item.title: China remembers Khaleda Zia’s contributions to Dhaka-Beijing ties
item.description: China has said BNP Chairperson and former Prime Minister Khaleda Zia’s important contributions to promoting Bangladesh-China friendship and the bilateral relationship will forever be remembered. “Khaleda Zia is an old and dear friend of Chinese people and long committed to China-Bangla

item.title: Chief adviser greets countrymen on New Year 2026
item.description: Chief Adviser Professor Muhammad Yunus has greeted all the Bangladeshis living in the country and abroad at the advent of English New Year 2026'.
